captions.text: Today it comes out.

In no uncertain terms, by
the time we're done today,

you will know exactly
where the cat daddy stands.

People, let's talk
about declawing.
It's very simple.

I mean, declawing is something
that I come across every day.

25% of all cats in
the US are declawed,
which is crazy when you ask me.
Why is it crazy?

Because declawing is,
in my humble opinion,

inhumane, barbaric, for
the most part cosmetic,
and it is unnecessary.
What is declawing?

Declawing is actually
de-knuckling.

You think that all you're
doing is pulling out

the claws of a cat to make
your belongings safer,
or your kids, or you.
But it's not.

It is the amputation
of the first joint

of every knuckle
on a cat's paws.
I'm here to talk for the cats.

And the cats say,
of course I wouldn't
want my knuckles amputated.
And for what reason?

We're removing the initial
line of defense for a cat.

When a cat tries to get your
attention because they don't

like what's going
on, then they're
going to pat pat at you.

If you don't get that message,
then the claws come out.

Hey, I'm trying to
tell you something.

And the third line of
defense is their teeth.
That's when they bite.

So when a cat gets
their claws taken away

because you think you're
going to be safer,
I'm telling you what.

You're going to get bit
more often than not.

Cats who are declawed
are more likely to get
surrendered to shelters.
Why is that?

Usually because of
secondary symptoms,

a cat goes in the litter box for
the first time after surgery.
It hurts.

A cat doesn't say,
wow, my paws hurt.

What they say when they
step in the litter box
is that place hurts.
And why would I go back there?

Yeah, no reasonable
cat would go back
into something that hurts them.
So they stop.

And cats who are
declawed then wind up
with litter box problems.
That's when I meet them.

Let's also talk about what we're
doing to a cat's physiology.
We are changing it.

Cats are what we
call digitigrade.
They walk on their tiptoes.

And when we change the
formation of their paws, poot,
they sink down.
Please, think about it.

Later on in life, are they
more susceptible to arthritis,
for instance?

Of course they
are, because we've

changed the way
nature made them.

Now, do cats who
suffer declawing

have problems
defending themselves?
Sure they do.

Declawed cats have a
hard time climbing trees
to get away from predators.

Even though vets
are still performing

declawing to a large
degree, they'll

still say, keep
your cat indoors,

because they have trouble
defending themselves outdoors.

Is declining with
a laser better?

It's less messy,
sure, but there have

been papers published that
say that there is absolutely

no correlation between
laser declawing

and a decrease in the amount
of chronic pain and discomfort

that a cat will experience,
none whatsoever.

Declawing is so
predictably painful

that pharmaceuticals
actually use it

as a measure to test
pain medication.

Guys, 22 countries
on record, and I'm

sure more at this
point, have banned
declawing, whole countries.

Now, we've been
fighting in the States

to ban it city by city
because of some arcane laws

that prevent us from going
after the states, at least

in California, but entire
countries, 22 of them.

Well, the one thing
I don't want to do

is come across as
somebody who is

wagging their
finger at everybody.
That's not who I am.
I swear to you.

I'm an educator and a
student for the most part.

But I'm here to tell you
that it's forgivable.

If you said, oh, my
grandparents declawed.

My mom declawed her
cats, so I declawed mine.

It's fine if you're
learning right now.

If you refuse to look at
both anecdotal and scientific

evidence and you don't
listen to me, someone

who has been in the field for 20
years working with these cats,

then I have a hard time
forgiving, because you

are going against what
you know about your cats.

If you want to learn more about
declawing, well, first of all
there's me.

And you will find articles
on cats, scratching,

and how cats can live happily
ever after on my website.

As a matter of fact, you
probably see a link for it
right there.

But also another link right
there would be pawproject.org.

Man, you got lots of
great information there.

But here, this is what
I'm going to be doing.
I'll be giving away two.

Count them, two copies
of The Paw Project movie.

I will autograph it, sign it
to you, or your favorite cat,

or someone that you're
trying to educate.

I'll sign their name
right on here as well.
And it is a fantastic movie.
So stay tuned, guys.

All you've got do is leave
a comment on the bottom

of this here page,
subscribe to this channel,

and you are entered
automatically
to win one of these movies.

And hurry up, because you only
have a short amount of time
to do this.

More information to
follow, so please subscribe
and you'll find out more.

title: Declawing: Jackson Galaxy Just Says No!

comments.text:
I completely agree with this video. I had to make a small exception with my 
boy Timmy though. When I got him as a kitten, he already had nerve damage 
to his left front leg which made his paw bend like the end of a golf club 
or hockey stick. It sure doesn't slow him down any, he can get around with 
no problem and loves hanging out on top of my fridge, but since he couldn't 
control those claws he kept getting them caught in his scratching post. 
Sometimes he'd wind up dragging his post across the floor before I could 
make it to him and help get his claws free. I was worried getting stuck 
like that wouldn't be good for his leg, so I had that one paw declawed and 
he hasn't had any trouble with his post since then. Due to his disability 
Timothy's an indoor cat, but just in case he ever manages to get out he 
still has three good clawed paws to work with if ever he needs to defend 
himself.﻿
comments.author: Les C.

comments.text:
I totally agree and understand how detrimental and cruel declawing is, but 
I do have one question after watching this. If veterinarians know its 
cruel, painful, and leaves the cat defenseless, why do (most) perform the 
surgery? I've watched the Paw Project and it hints at it, but I just don't 
fully understand if it's all about greed or...?﻿
comments.author: Tiffany Lynn

comments.text:
When we got my cat almost 12 years ago at this point from the ASPCA we had 
to sign an oath that we would never declaw her. We never even humored the 
thought. My cat was feral before we got her with time and handling we no 
longer had to take her to the vet to have her nails clipped I could do it 
myself. If you're worried about your furniture they have scratching posts 
as well as double sided tape that can help discourage clawing furniture. My 
cat kept doing it to my moms favorite chair so I bought a vertical scratch 
post and set it against the spot she always clawed and as she started using 
that I gradually moved it away from the couch. People who declaw are 
looking for an instant solution or they don't know better. If you're scared 
of handling your cat yourself one you need to work on trust between 
yourself and the gag and two you can take the cat to the vet to have them 
bathed and clipped by people who know how to safely handle aggressive cats. 
We did that with my sisters cat too because we couldn't handle her with my 
sister being gone in the military and it want expensive. ﻿
comments.author: Taylor Richardson

comments.text:
I really don't like the idea of declawing cats, but I think there can be 
exceptions. My cat is declawed. He wasn't my cat at the time, but I knew 
him, and I think in this case, it was probably the best option. He lived 
with two older cats with declining health, both declawed, during his 
adolescence in a mostly unsupervised home. He laid such a beating on the 
two of them and they, having no claws, were basically defenseless. I can't 
think of another way to have solved that problem without having to confine 
one or all of the cats all day. The real answer would have been not 
declawing the other two cats, but their owner didn't have much education on 
that. He did have some minor litter box issues, but he's well past them 
now, and I'm doing my best to make sure the rest of his life is as happy 
and painless as possible.﻿
comments.author: nottilthursday

comments.text:
I rescued a great cat off the streets. Oki had been living out in the cold 
in an Adirondack town...with no claws. But Oki could never jump down from a 
table without rapping his knuckles on the floor because his previous owner 
had him declawed before letting him out in the street. I know it hurt! He 
was an obsessive licker for the rest of his life. He knew there was 
something wrong with him, though. It made both of us sad. We coped with it. 
He died from an unrelated illness and I miss him, weird behavior and all.﻿
comments.author: Sally Eckhoff

comments.text:
I would never declaw a cat, cats need their claws for so many reasons. Not 
only that but I imagine the pain would be akin to getting ones fingernails 
pulled. Difference is that fingernails grow back, claws don't. and they are 
forced to walk on those wounds for life.﻿
comments.author: colleen swiggum

comments.text:
I got 2 kittens 18 years ago, and got their front feet declawed.  I didn't 
understand what was involved and I really wish I would have known more 
about the procedure.  I never would have done it, and will never do it 
again.  I hope this message gets out to more people and it never happens to 
another cat/kitten again.  Thank you Jackson, and keep sending out the 
message.  Gotta keep our fur babies safe.﻿
comments.author: Barb Anderson

comments.text: Mine r never declawed﻿
comments.author: visini Pathirana

comments.text: Hello!﻿
comments.author: Rowan123 Arrowood

comments.text:
Nether do claws unless they are just trimmed never declew a cat unless you 
want behavior problems such as aggression,pooping/peeing out side the 
little box,not eating ecc as for physical crippled paws, pain for the rest 
of there life ecc cats need there claws for a lot of things even walking 
with out them they will walk on there heels with will be damaging to the 
leg it self until they can't walk at all without severe pain also for 
useing the litter box and if it escaped and got into danger it would have 
no way to defend it self when you declaw a cat you arnt just takeing the 
nail the nail is attached to a bone so actually your takeing the nail and 
the bottom part of the toe also they are awake during this process and it 
painful not just then but the pain last long after that so if your for 
declawing just hold up your hand because declawing a cat is like cutting 
off your fingers ﻿
comments.author: brittbate13

comments.text: what colors r russian blues?﻿
comments.author: Zoe Foster

comments.text:
My cat is declawed and she had it done when she was about 6 months old. She 
is now 18 years old. I had no say in the surgery as I was only about 7, but 
she didn't suffer any adverse effects. She's perfectly fine and a very 
happy cat. Yes I see the problems that can happen because of declawing but 
that doesn't mean you're torturing or crippling your cat. It's up to you if 
you want to or not that's all I have to say.﻿
comments.author: Tarienlover

comments.text:
What?! I have heard about smth like this first time in my live and i have 
cat 9 yrs and read a lot about cats. How could even someone think about 
this? i.. i.. omg :( I dont believe ppl doing that...﻿
comments.author: kormag1

comments.text:
i do not think its wrong as long as u only cut the tippy top or just get a 
scratching post and train the cat to go there. There, so simple!!✨💙﻿
comments.author: Raina rashid

comments.text:
+Raina rashid Declawing IS NOT the same as clipping claws.Watch & listen to 
whole video.
So glad I live in UK where this cruel practice is illegal
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
were i live declawing isnt a thing, and im happy about it! here , they only 
cut their claws (not all the way of course, they only trim them) and it 
really helps, it doesnt hurt that much when they accidently scratch you, 
but they can still protect themselves :)﻿
comments.author: carmen akkerman

comments.text:
i am glad my country banned declawing who in there right mind declaw a cat 
they neec their claws﻿
comments.author: crystalaura45

comments.text: +crystalaura45 Same Here
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
Hi Jackson would you equivelate de-clawing to the practice of spaying/ 
neutering? ﻿
comments.author: Abram Ke

comments.text: +Abram Ke I already have been. Have U?
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
+Abram Ke As far as the question "is there something wrong with spaying and 
neutering of animals?" then yes, this is a topic worth talking about. But 
as far as de-clawing and spaying/neutering being equally wrong, I don't see 
how the two are comparable at all. First of all, de-clawing directly 
impacts the quality of life for a cat, whereas the spaying and neutering of 
an animal, as far as short term physiological and psychological effects 
goes, only stops their yearning for genetic propagation and the obvious 
ability to do so. It's definitely a topic for discussion, but comparing 
de-clawing to spaying/neutering can both downplay how destructive 
de-clawing can be, and makes spaying and neutering seem equally deplorable 
as de-clawing.
comments.author: Azzury Street

comments.text: So many positives maybe you should also go see a doctor on getting spayed.
comments.author: Abram Ke

comments.text:
I used appendix mearly as an example. I could also have said gall bladder, 
it's still abdominal surgery. We do know the long term effects of 
neutering. No chance of sexual organ cancer in future is 100% guaranteed. 
Less chance of mammary or prostrate cancer has also been proven by decades 
of research. I could continue, but I suggest you do your own research. 
Anyway point I was making was that declawing is not the same as other 
surgeries you mention. It is a mutilation with no purpose except to please 
people.
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
Testis, and ovaries aren't vestigial structures like appendixes and so your 
statement is invalid. Besides, we dont know the long- term effects of 
removal of the testis, and ovaries have on our animals.
comments.author: Abram Ke

comments.text:
+Abram Ke Two totally different things.How would you like your finger tips 
amputated and someone say it's no worse than an appendix removal?
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
My first cat, who I am convinced was my soul mate before he passed, was 
declawed as a kitten. My dad adamantly insisted on it because a cat he had 
with my mom before I was born scratched the hell out of him constantly. My 
mom didn't know any better so she agreed, and I was 5 so I had no clue what 
they were even talking about. We were lucky that he never had any problems 
walking or using the litter box or having any kind of severe pain. When I 
found out what declawing was I vowed to never have a cat declawed again. My 
second cat that I adopted after my first passed away came from a shelter. 
She was a stray that someone tried to raise but ended up having to give her 
up. When I took her home, my dad immediately demanded that we get her 
declawed. At this point I had educated my mom on the horrors of declawing 
so she was on my side about not declawing. We've had her for 3 years now 
and she doesn't scratch the furniture, has never scratched my dad even once 
(she gets me all the time though, but I don't care lol), and tolerates me 
clipping her nails just fine.﻿
comments.author: Bridget Lysaght

comments.text: Omy god im crying﻿
comments.author: Anahi Corral

comments.text:
Nobody should ever declaw a cat because how would like it if something you 
loved for years came up to you and just cut your fingers off?﻿
comments.author: The Twolf Awesome

comments.text:
I'll never do it with my cat!!! That's so cruel! I love her just the way 
she is!﻿
comments.author: Juliana Esperidião

comments.text:
i tried watching the paw project on netflix and it was too sad, my late 
childhood cat was declawed and once he hit 8 years he had horrible 
arthritis and social problems, you could hear him thumping around the 
house. his paws werent even flexible either they were like balled up fists, 
stuck like that forever. declawing is horrible. if you dont want you cat to 
scratch trim there claws and get a cat tree! simple and painless.﻿
comments.author: Ash Lilyvale

comments.text:
I remember when my roommate was asked if she was going to de-claw her cat 
by someone. She was like "Are you crazy? My cat is BLIND and you think 
de-clawing a BLIND cat is a good idea?! He already has a hard time trusting 
strangers that come to the house. Why would I break his trust in me by 
crippling him further?"﻿
comments.author: HitomiNoRyu

comments.text:
I have also heard that there is a right and wrong way to clip cat nails. 
Due to the shape, the interior of the nail is soft tissue that you have to 
make sure you don't sever. Go ahead and trim your cat's nails but I'm just 
saying be careful you don't clip too far down the nail.﻿
comments.author: Alizah High

comments.text:
Correction: By "soft tissue" I mean the quick of the nail which is filled 
with sensitive nerves and blood vessels. It is visibly pink so you 
shouldn't have trouble knowing how far down to cut but if you do, your cats 
nail will bleed and he/she will most likely flinch and have a bad 
association with the process and refuse it more often.
comments.author: Alizah High

comments.text:
declawing damages cats. The vet profession does not even know the anatomy 
of a cat's paw yet! Is there an extensor tendon attachment on the dorsal P2 
in the cat's paw? Double dare you to answer!﻿
comments.author: rgaskinDVM

comments.text:
Yesss! You agree! If a cat goes missing, there's dogs EVERYWHERE in my 
neighborhood, I've lost 2 cats, they can't protect themselves against the 
dogs, and they're the big dogs. It may rip up a sofa but it may save the 
cats life also. I say no!﻿
comments.author: TheSpiritedStar

comments.text:
I just have to say that I am a supporter of making declawing illegal 
everywhere in the world. I personally don't see any good reason for 
declawing. It would be far better to give the cat to a loving home, then to 
put the poor thing through such a traumatic experience needlessly. Caps may 
or may not work. I may be wrong, but I think that some vets are willing to 
put the caps on for you. However, don't quote me on that, as I could be 
completely mistaken about that. Regardless, please, please, please, don't 
declaw your cats...especially if it's only to protect your furniture. If 
you have a new baby or young children, that's a better reason, but I'd 
still rather see that cat given away to a good home.﻿
comments.author: kokobo63

comments.text:
Us against declawing will not be berated into agreeing with a Pro-Declaw 
stance. We have no issues holding a respectful discussion and exchanging 
facts. However there is a certain point where reasoning between both sides 
does not happen. Your opinion for declawing has been heard. That is why 
countries still do this. Just because your cats have not had issues that 
you are aware of does not mean it should be accepted. Just look to history 
to realize some of the most barbaric, inhumane actions that have shown 
partial proof of success were still accepted by society for many years.
Some points we would like to address:
1. Banning declawing will raise the rate of homelessness, displaced, 
abused, abandoned and euthanized cats:
Yes it is true some people do not like cats scratching their furniture. But 
there are alternatives to declawing. There are thousands of declawed cats 
in rescues and shelters across the United States alone. Apparently being 
declawed did not save them from this fate. So how is this a valid point of 
a Pro-Declaw stance? If someone is going to abandon an animal please know 
that any excuse will do. 
A majority of people who own cats do love cats. When getting a cat you 
accept things. The same can be said of any animal. Animals can be trained 
and behavior can be changed. And honestly even when behavior is not changed 
a majority of us will accept this "fault" because we love our animals as a 
whole. Once you begin to allow changes to an animal you bring so much in 
question. If we accept this than we believe any alteration to an animal 
that is beneficial for the owner is acceptable with no regards to the 
animal. If you want a particular kind of animal that does not do certain 
things there are many other options. 
If you medically need to own a declawed cat, which in some cases elderly 
and people with weakened immune systems or thin blood, may feel it is the 
only choice then please adopt one! There are so many out there waiting for 
you and that need a home.
If someone is going to abuse an animal for doing something that comes 
naturally then anything the animal does may leave them opened to abuse. 
Claiming one thing will lead to abuse is not acceptable. An abuser will 
abuse without reason needed because they are abuser.
2. Spay/Neuter surgery is on the same level as declawing.
Spay/Neuter is not only beneficial to you and the pet population but it is 
also beneficial to your animal. Animals that are fixed not only live 
longer, but they are less likely to get certain diseases and illnesses. 
Declawing is truly only beneficial to one party. It is an unneeded surgery 
that puts your cat at risk. And yes there are risks with any operations, 
however in some surgeries the benefits outweigh the risks.
3. The horror stories you hear are such a small percent of declawing, 
therefore the majority of declawing is successful and needed:
So as long as just a few suffer this is ok? The mentality of this argument 
just does not make sense. It is more than a few cats that suffer after 
being declawed. And we go back to why risk it when there are alternatives 
we can use to avoid it?
4. My Vet says it is totally safe:
Get a new Vet as soon as possible. If your Vet is not upfront with the 
risks and possibilities of issues your animal may have for ANY procedure 
then they care more about your money than your animal. A good Vet will be 
upfront with you, voice any concerns, go into details and be realistic with 
you. If your Vet does not do this then you are cheating your animal and 
also yourself. A good Vet will care about the well being of your animal. 
And in some cases actually be cheaper than a Vet who is only in it to make 
profit.
5. Declawing would already be banned everywhere if it was truly barbaric 
and inhumane:
Again please refer to history. So many tragedies, injustices, and 
ill-informed procedures were considered the normal until someone stood up 
and spoke against them. Once more just because things are accepted by 
society does not make them right.
We can go on and on addressing points we consider true myths of declawing. 
However it is up to you as a human being to make an informed decision. We 
have chosen compassion over convenience as our stance. And at the end of 
the day we can live with our decision. If you end up being one of the "few" 
that mutilate, disfigured, maimed or scarred your cat for life can you live 
with yours?﻿
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
Everyone of you for declawing needs to shut up. Jackson knows cats and what 
he's talking about! You don't!! ﻿
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
Here is a quote from a vet receptionist: 
"I was a receptionist for a vet and have seen complaints about cats after 
being declawed. They can be aggressive, less social or friendly, and 
display other behavior problems. In fact, I’ve seen a couple cats in my 
short time there come to us to be put down because the behavior was 
intolerable. Yes, we perform vasectomies and hysterectomies on both humans 
and cats, but how many people out there cut half their fingers off because 
they can’t tolerate their nails?"﻿
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
I find it really sad that these so called cat lovers and owners would put 
them through this unnesscery and also beyond cruelty thing! No real cat 
lovers will do this!! ﻿
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
It's pretty sad that after people saw this video and know what cats go 
through they still want to fight on it and they have no ground to what they 
say. ﻿
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
My beautiful boy doesn't scratch up the furniture :). He goes straight to 
the scratching posts. What really makes me mad is, a lot of the people who 
declaw their cats (not all but most) don't even own something specifically 
for the cat to scratch!!! I mean, it's in their blood to scratch and it 
feels good to them. Also a lot of those people don't bother to try to get 
their cats active in play. That also helps. So like most of the folks in 
the comments are saying, I agree that if can't take responsibility for 
him/her, please let someone else adopt them. Sorry it's late where I am and 
I'm having trouble wording things lol :P﻿
comments.author: Kiwi Holmes

comments.text:
after watching this video  i agree that cat's don't need this to happen!! 
trimming is what i alway's do and i will tell everyone i know to do the 
same!  trimming is best! thanks alot for your video's!!!﻿
comments.author: Thomas Rand

comments.text:
I'm not saying declawing is OK, but I declawed my cat and I saw no effects. 
She was fine the next day and still had all of the agility she had when she 
had claws. There was no recovery time and she walks how she did with claws. 
She is happy and healthy and she has been declawed for several years. I 
just don't see any huge issues with it. ﻿
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
I don't know. I tried the actual "Soft Paws" and a knockoff brand and I 
applied them both several times. They would just come off.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
I also used soft paws on my cats and I also used a lot of glue. Maybe the 
reason why yours didn't work because you didn't used a lot more glue.
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text:
+Lannie90210 I didn't really intend to get a cat, she was a kitten and I 
decided to foster her after her mother was killed and she was orphaned. My 
dog and cat made a bond and they became best friends. We soon discovered my 
cat had separation anxiety when someone tried to adopt the kitten. It 
wasn't good for her health to keep them apart so I decided to keep the cat. 
Soon after, however, my cat began to claw my dog when they played together. 
She would use her claws to get on top of my dog and my dog got an infection 
on her muzzle from a cat scratch mark. We tried trimming her nails, nail 
caps, and training but none of that worked. (We needed a quick solution to 
prevent my dog from getting a serious injury. The longer it took the more 
likely my dog was going to get hurt.) We tried to re-home my cat, but she 
still had separation anxiety. Then we decided to get her claws removed for 
her benefit and my dogs. It was the best option for both of them, and now 
they live together happily and my cat no longer has separation anxiety.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
If you think it's not okay then why did you do it? When Orko was a kitten 
and when I first got Chloe. My other cats also clawed their eyes out. Fast 
forward 7 and 5 years later. All cats both have their eyes and their claws. 
I also have a cat that bites hard. Should I get them removed because of 
it?. I also have dogs. Should I removed their teeth and claws? Also just 
because she doesn't have any ill effects now from doesn't mean it won't 
happen. This cat on FB ending up getting tumors from her declaw. Just 
because could things happen is a very reason not do to it.
comments.author: Lannie90210

comments.text: Anyone that De-Knuckles is a KnuckleHead.﻿
comments.author: Mitchell McCreath

comments.text:
As a vet assistant, few things make me more nervous than having to work 
with a declawed cat...they are absolutely more likely to try and bite, in 
my personal experience.Thankfully they are few and far between. The 
hospital I work in will not do the procedure, and hopefully more will 
follow suit. 
As a cat lover, my three cats still have their claws and always will. My 
couch looks like crap and I get occasional scratches when they play too 
rough, but I would never dream of declawing them, even with a baby on the 
way (despite pressure from in laws). My daughter will learn to love and 
respect her furry siblings, claws and all 😄﻿
comments.author: Jenn12141983

comments.text:
Out here in New Mexico, when you adopt a cat, they give you a packet 
telling you why is bad. My vet told us almost no vet, at least here, would 
do it unless there was an extreme circumstance.﻿
comments.author: Marie Gonzales

comments.text:
I just had to declaw my cat on the 13th. I don't agree with doing it in any 
way shape or form but I had no choice. My apartment building refuses to let 
you have a cat unless he/she is fixed and declawed. Now that my cats 
surgery is done she has been miserable the past few days and I am not sure 
if it's because she is older then most cats are when it happens. She only 
lost her claws on her 2 front paws but I am not happy with what I had to 
do. ﻿
comments.author: Rachael Johnson

comments.text: Well Done!
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:

comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

Guys if you can't handle a cat scratch then don't get a cat I have a cat

well money is key in this world they don't care the the cat is in pain all

comments.author: Dima dip

comments.text:
I've got 5 rescue cats. I love them to bits. Yes, I had to get a tetanus 
shot at one stage. So bloody what? I threw a cover over the couch and 
plenty of scratching posts and mats around the house. Is it really that 
hard? To me they are like family. And would one really want to mutilate a 
family member? If you don't think of them as family members, then I suggest 
you don't have any pets.﻿
comments.author: CateSimulate

comments.text:
+CateSimulate So good to hear you rescue cats and love them for what they 
are, cats. I have 7 cats all of whom were rescued. All our family get 
tetanus boosters every 5yrs. Why do other ppl moan about needing shots 
after a cat scratch? It should be a done thing like flu jabs etc. Standard 
preventative medicine.
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
I have noticed the comments saying that there is no problem for the cat, 
but for all the people who say that, imagine taking your hand and taking 
off the ends of your finger from its knuckle. Sure your can still be able 
to live but your will be disabled. Its inhumane and and cruel "human" your 
would declaw their cat so their would be safe, you could easily train your 
cat, thats what i did and Mr. Galaxy even talks about training your cat and 
its not all that difficult. So please care for your cat and stand up 
against amputating cat's paws and get declawing banned in the U.S. And 
everywhere else!﻿

We got rid of my cat because she poops outside the litter box and she hurts

favour and stay pet free.
comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
Do the cats a favour, and don't get other cats. Your attitude stinks 
towards them. They deserve a forever home with loving guardians.

comments.author: -Catsrock237 -

comments.text:
So if you HAVE de-clawed your cat (do not), you should remove the litter 
box and clean up the inevitable mess until they're healed. Put the box 
where they had used the restroom on the floor. Though, if you're lazy 
enough to de-claw when you KNOW better, I doubt you'll be willing to put up 
with the mess.

Got my first cat (had them growing up) - NOT de-clawing. It's not that 
inconvenient. Unfortunately my rescue needs a trim pretty much on day two 
and isn't comfortable enough to sit still yet! Also having no experience 
doesn't help. 

I've been grabbing her paws gently/playfully non-stop and then letting go 
after 2-3 seconds when we interact. Do you think I should let her get used 
to the place a few more days before actually trimming?﻿
comments.author: diet lime

comments.text:
Thank you Jackson! We adopted a cat who was already declawed. He had nerve 
damage in one of his paws as a result. He would keep it tucked and limp 
most of the time. Our vet said that this is not uncommon. Declawing is 
CRUEL! ﻿
comments.author: Leah Barber

comments.text:
Nobody and I mean nobody should declaw there cat it's against nature!it's 
the only defense mechanism they have!imagine your self with out your hands 
how terrible would you feel?﻿
comments.author: Bobby Mooi

comments.text:
I hope America one day follows the lead of nations like Brazil, Estonia and 
most (if not all) of Europe in banning this procedure﻿

comments.text:
I was watching an episode of My Cat From Hell and you said how it causes

their toes. I told my mom about that and she said she would never declaw a

comments.text: Thank you Jackson for adding your voice to the declaw discussion. ﻿

comments.text: Its cruel.  Illegal in Australia.﻿
comments.author: Mitchell McCreath

comments.text:
First time ever I heard about declawing (I'm from the Netherlands where 
this apparently is banned as an act of animal cruelty for good reasons!!).
What a barbaric practice and really hard to imagine why people even feel 
this should be done! Is it the expensive furniture? Well perhaps providing 
ways for the cat not to be bored might stop it from clawing at the couch. 
Or providing the proper scratch post for that matter. Does it hurt when 
getting scratched? Probably the cat already has been antagonized to a point 
it actually feels the need to use the claws. There is many signs in the 
body language before the big guns come out usually. Don't blame the cat for 
being a cat and leave the claws on.﻿

comments.author: Jennifer A Shepherd

comments.text:
Absolute unbelievable, I did not even know that this is done to so many

Hope very much that this will be changed soon in the US. Good luck from

comments.author: Petra Sch

comments.text:
My friend adopted a declawed cat recently...something new for her. Sue's 
parents had outdoor cats and so did she. Claws were never an issue even 
when the cats came inside. Remmy does what Jackson was talking about: pat 
you with the paw, then a claw comes out, then a nip. Just minus the claw. 
This is usually if he gets overstimulated, and cats DO that. The pupils 
open up and they go into Hunter Mode. Your hand is prey. If you're a kid, 
or have kids, that's good to know. It's not the cat's fault...the cat is 
being a cat. Don't piss it off if you can help it, and learn from your vet 
the safe way to handle your cat in emergencies without getting clawed or 
bitten. And we clipped our cats' nails from kittenhood, so a few are okay 
with it.        
we have 7 cats, btw. 2 cattery-bought Maine Coons, 2 that were left by a 
dumpster as kittens and would've turned wild-like in time, 1 that was 
"dumped" on us (if we didn't take him, we was going to the shelter. That 
kitten is the star of my life.) and 2 shelter cats (PITA is an Oriental 
Shorthair mix, Bugsy is a red tabby Maine Coon mix.)﻿
comments.author: StinzandL

comments.text:
how many vet inform their clients what declawing is?

i was going to have my cat declawed, thinking is was just trimming their

comments.author: Rafael Ayala

comments.text:
So sad that something like this has to be 'banned' & it's more a shame more 
Vets don't educate their clients about how wrong declawing is. It's not 
just inhuman, it's selfish. Please educate yourself before choosing a pet & 
dont take a Vet's word as gospel as many, not all, are more interested on 
your payment than what is best for your pet. Example: I love all animals, 
more than most people; and I really prefer dogs as pets. However, I work 
long hours & don't have a very big yard, so I have cats, 3 to be exact, as 
they are less dependent on human care as dogs. They are all fully clawed & 
can defend themselves if need be. 25 years as a cat owner & I have never 
had one single piece of furniture, not a friend nor family member harmed 
because of it  :-) Good luck & may the Force be with you.﻿
comments.author: 1mecj

comments.text:
Very Nice Youtube Vid Jackson, Now if only we could pressure the Vets that 
keep Declawing the cats in Cities that haven't outlawed it yet. Couldn't 
this be considered animal abuse and be fined under some Law? Im not trying 
to do away with Vets we need them to spay and neuter our pets and nurse 
them back to good health when they get sick, but cant we make it so its non 
profitable to declaw? Maybe protest the ones that keep up this practice? Or 
Start a Wall of Shame Website? Anyways keep up the good work even if its 
just saving 1 cat at a time. For those who are still adamant about 
declawing do your next cat a favor and just buy a Fish Tank instead Thanks﻿
comments.author: Leafbinder

comments.text:
We are so grateful to our wonderful vet for providing us with the truth of

though they are only indoor cats.  Simply barbaric.  It takes 2 mins to

fussy cat.  Easy choice to make.﻿

comments.author: noh1312

comments.text:
Luckily, in the UK, declawing, tail docking, ear trimming and other evil 
cosmetic animal procedures are illegal. As an amputee, I can imagine how a 
declawed cat feels post surgery, neuropathic pain and phantom pain drives 
you half mad where nerves and bone have been cut and arrogant, ignorant 
people do this to save furniture? I'd like to see them try to type an email 
with the 1st digit of every one of their fingers removed. Barbaric 
practice...﻿
comments.author: Jargon Ellie

comments.text:

comments.author: Beautystage01

comments.text:
I just rescued a cat like 3 hours ago after getting her home we have 
noticed and I'm about 95% sure she's deaf! So what's the best thing to do 
to make her happy?!! We love her SO much she's so Sweet! So we'll do 
whatever it takes to make her happy! Still haven't introduced her to our 2 
dogs or cat... ? Not sure how todo that to also let her know she's safe 
with put her hearing... so basically I want to know how to introduce a deaf 
cat to dogs and a cat as well as how to make sure she lives a long happy 
life﻿
comments.author: nikkirukavina1992

comments.text:
Whatever you do, do it gently and slowly. Deaf cats "hear" by vibration. If 
you need to get the cat's attention, gently pat the floor. If your dogs are 
gentle with the cat, make the introduction slow and allow the cat an escape 
route should they feel scared. Over time, your cat will know the vibrations 
your dog makes and be more comfortable. Keeping a routine will help with a 
hearing impaired cat. If you feed them at the same time everyday, they 
won't need to "hear" the food being poured/opened to know it's time to get 
their grub on. Just some tips. :)
comments.author: broadwaykitten

comments.text:
Any one have a link to a nail clipping video (I'm on a tablet and the 
search channel function isn't there) my cat needs her nails clipped as she 
is VERY lazy and doesn't like to walk on concrete or scratch so she has 
very long claws at the moment. I want to clip them but I'm scared of 
mopping the mail bed, I can't take her to the vet because she would most 
probably die from a heart attack (she starts that horrible puffing whenever 
she goes to the vet and also mutilates nurses etc. She can't be gassed or

comments.author: TheStarStrangled

comments.text:
How is this still a thing? I cannot believe that declawing a cat is still 
legal in certain (western and civilised!) countries. It has been banned in 
my country and the countries around it, and I really wish every other 
country would do the same. And no, cats in shelters here are not euthanised 
either, so even if a person gets rid of their cat, the shelter will find 
them a good home with sane owners, even if it takes a year (I know, I owned 
a shelter cat and some of the cats were there for a year, leading 
relatively good lives. Last time I checked all of them had been adopted!). 
That's a different matter though, sorry for going off topic.

Can't stand your cat acting like a cat? Get an ant farm or something.﻿

comments.text:
Please, sign the following petition. Be a part of putting an end to this

comments.author: Kiwi Holmes

comments.text:
Do it. If you can give that cat a proper home for the rest of his life, 
then give that cat a proper home. Declawed cats need love too!

helped me understand him tremendously. Thx ^_^﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: JuJu Crafts

comments.text:
I'm 100% against declawing my lil pals, thats they are outdoor strays that 
basically live on my front porch and they need those claws for defense 
against predators.﻿
